This is not a recent trend but a durable shift in public opinion, largely driven by voter fatigue with the long-serving Liberal government and persistent economic anxieties around inflation and housing, which are core themes of the Conservative message. The Liberal party has historically proven to be a resilient and effective campaign machine, and a six-month timeframe allows for unforeseen events or shifts in public sentiment.

My forecast is not lower because the scale and duration of the Conservative lead are substantial. The core issues driving their support (economic discontent, desire for change) are deeply entrenched and unlikely to be resolved before the election. Overcoming such a large deficit would require a historic comeback by the incumbent Liberals.

I would increase my probability if the Conservative lead remains at or above 10 points into the fall campaign season. I would decrease my probability if the polling gap narrows to within 5 points, or if the Liberals change leaders and receive a significant and lasting polling boost.
